Robo-Reporting: How Artificial Intelligence Is Assisting Journalists in the NewsroomAuthor Martech10/18/2019

Jeremy Gilbert, Director of Strategic Initiatives at The Washington Post, discusses the implementation artificial intelligence tools in the newsroom, allowing human journalists to put their time into more significant reporting.

            <h1 class="entry-title post-title">Robo-Reporting: How Artificial Intelligence Is Assisting Journalists in the Newsroom</h1>        </header><!-- .entry-header -->
            	
	<div class="post-entry">
		<p><iframe src="https://player.pippa.io/5bec741aa6bbfb7c4e7357d9/episodes/jeremy-gilbert?theme=white&cover=1&latest=1" frameBorder="0" width="100%" height="110px" allow="autoplay"></iframe></p>
<p><em>As artificial intelligence moves from the realm of science fiction to reality, many questions remain about the effects it will have on the American workforce, particularly regarding its potential to displace workers and eliminate jobs. In this episode of </em>Mastering Innovation<em> on Sirius XM Channel 132, <a href="https://businessradio.wharton.upenn.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Business Radio Powered by The Wharton School</a>, Jeremy Gilbert, Director of Strategic Initiatives at the </em>Washington Post<em>, presents a positive view of AI’s growing role in journalism. He discusses the newspaper’s recent implementation of new artificial intelligence tools that are now executing simple tasks in the newsroom, freeing up journalists to conduct more substantial reporting.</em></p>
<p><em>Often a poster child of post-internet disruption, print journalism has had to scramble to adapt to the digital age as revenues wane and social media and independent online news outlets compete for readers’ attention. To enhance the breadth and depth of its reporting, the </em>Post <em>has been experimenting with a new automated program called Heliograf, which can present wide swaths of factual information and keep it continuously updated more effectively than a human can. Gilbert elaborates on the intricacies of the AI-powered tool and its use during the 2018 midterm elections, which the </em>Post <em>used to cover congressional races across the country.</em></p>
<p><em>An excerpt of the interview is transcribed below. <a href="https://mackinstitute.wharton.upenn.edu/events-and-programs/business-radio/">Listen to more episodes here.</a></em></p>

<p><strong>Saikat Chaudhuri:</strong> I’ve been reading a lot about the AI tools Heliograf and ModBot. Can you tell us about that?</p>

At the end of the day, we have some of the world’s best reporters, and we invest very heavily in that. We’re never looking to replace them. <p><strong>Chaudhuri:</strong> That resonates with me. <p><strong>Chaudhuri:</strong> Fascinating. Clearly, you’re on the cutting edge and doing a lot of great things at the<em> Washington Post</em>. <blockquote><p>“If you’re in the storytelling business, you cannot be completely devoted to the channel that you publish in.” – Jeremy Gilbert</p></blockquote>
<p><strong>Gilbert:</strong> There are a couple of things that have worked at the <em>Post</em>. We got incredibly lucky when the Graham family sold the <em>Washington Post</em> in the fall of 2013. <p><em>As director of strategic initiatives at the </em>Washington Post<em>, Jeremy Gilbert leads the newsroom to identify, create and execute unique digital products and storytelling experiences.
